The Pop Prize is an initiative of BV Pop and is presented by Buma Cultuur.

Winners of the Frisian bandprize in 2016, Pendants will get you moving with their energetic show and groovy beats. The band features Piter Reitsma, Gosse Scherstra, Anne Martin Koree and Tjerk Jansma, will submerge you in grand, atmospheric sounds and retro synthesizers.

NAMBYAR is an alternative R&B artist delivering a melancholic wave of analogue drum beats and synths with a dark soulful voice. Born Jesse Nambiar, this musician, songwriter and producer grew up in a small town near Amsterdam and was always surrounded by nature. He has played the guitar since he was 9 years-old , but at 21 Jesse played in indie band Valerius which produced a number 1 hit in Indonesia and got several songs on Dutch radio. After recording two albums with Valerius, it was time to go solo.

Born on a houseboat in Amsterdam, singer-songwriter Tolls (Daan van Beijeren) was raised by the gentle rolling of the waves. In 2015 he entered the studio and came out with Stolen Piece, a successful EP full of music influenced by indie folk and pop. He has since played shows all over Holland and was selected for two talent competitions.

To French saxophonist Guillaume Perret, jazz is an open invitation to throw in funk, surreal harmonies, breakneck metal, breathy arabesque, retro-African groove, and jam-band psychedelica. It's big-tent jazz, a sonic electro-shock bristling with a truly global range of influences. After the EP Doors and second release Open Me (2014) he released FREE in September, 2016. The third album picked up where the last left off with a recklessly beautiful adventure into unknown musical territory.

London-born and bred and a native of the London club scene, DJ and producer Siobhan Bell has been making waves since 2010. This young talent plays in clubs in New York, Paris and Amsterdam and produces a wide range of genres, from nostalgic R&B remixes to trap, grime and Jersey club. Her sets create an infectious energy, full of massive sounds that guarantee to force even the stiffest of souls on the dance floor.

Octa Push fuse music from the Portuguese speaking word (Angola, Bissau, Brazil, Cape Verde, Mozambique, Portugal, and Sao Tomé) with electronic sounds. This unique sound and a  live show with eye-catching visuals has taken the duo from Lisbon to Barcelona's Sonar Festival, RBMA Barcelona, Amsterdam Dance Event, Nos Alive, Rock in Rio Lisboa, and the legendary Fabric club in London. Their second album Lingua came out in September last year and pays tribute to 40 years of 'Portuguese' styles like Afro house, kuduro, fado, semba and morna.

What to expect of Moldova? Well, most likely a unique blend of heavy metal, hard rock and thrash metal. Tepes have been touring Eastern Europe for over nine years and are known for spicing up their intense live shows with cage dancers and more.

Subtle would be an understatement for Christian Löffler's super cool electronics. Mare is the second studio album by the German producer and it follows in a similar vein to his self-released debut, 2012's A Forest. However a key difference is that while his first album was heavily sample-based, Mare is much more organic, with nearly every sound and every instrument self-recorded, and, unsurprisingly, many of the album's ideas are based on field-recordings.

No need to chose between The Rolling Stones or The Beatles as Jacle Bow serves you the best of both bands. This young Brussels band brings rock 'n roll back to the epicentre of music. Jacle Bow is signed worldwide to Warner Music and is Artist In Residence 2016 at Belgium's greatest venue, Ancienne Belgique (AB). Their first two singles secured them airplay on several radio stations and their debut album, produced by Mario Goossens of Triggerfinger, is ready.

In the summer of 2016 Torus finally released his second EP on Rwina and it was worth the wait. On ENGINE MALFUNCTION MUSIC VOL. X [NO DJ] the producer from The Hague brings it down to a personalised, uncompromising truth and the finest filaments of trance, grime, jungle, gothic film soundtracks and sci-fi gangster rap, but always with a unique style and pattern. Joeri Woudstra is inspired by the LA beat scene and producers like Flying Lotus, Shlohmo and Nosaj Thing. And he's far from done, he has a new EP and album lined up for 2017.

Dardust provides a multi-dimensional live experience that goes from a fascinating and emotional classical set with a string trio, to a captivating electro set with stunning audiovisuals. The Italians are known for their amazing and explosive gigs influenced by neo-classical and electronic masters like Ludovico Einaudi, Olafur Arnalds, Nils Frahm and Jon Hopkins. They released their second album Birth in October 2016.

Mozes and the Firstborn burst onto the scene as major garage rock talents. They toured the States three times, released tracks on Burger Records and Top Notch and then went quiet. Turned out the crew from Eindhoven needed to dump their intended second album to throw off their shackles and be resurrected. Their second coming brought about a glam pop appearance with similarly addictive songs. Suits them well. Don't trust them when they sing Nowhere Bound.

Loop Alley is an electro wave band with one foot stuck in the eighties and the other kicking house in your face. Multi-instrumentalist/producer Nathan Drohm and Flemish vocalist Libbie started in 2011 as a 'looping' duo playing improvised tracks. In November 2015 they released debut EP Shimmering Sky. Then bass player Ruud Vleij joins and this collaboration produces tracks with influences from Moloko, Siouxsie and the Banshees and Dj Richie Hawtin.

Releasing his first mixtape in the spring of 2015, hip hop/R&B artist Sturla Atlas quickly made a name for himself as one of Iceland's most exciting new acts. He became known for his energetic stage performance along with 101 Boys, kept releasing music and garnered support from the likes of i-D, Hillydilly and The Line of Best Fit. Sturla Atlas was named Newcomer of the Year at the Icelandic Music Awards and his latest mixtape SEASON2, a cleverly produced electronic R&B fest, has been justifiably well received.

You have electronic dance pop and you have Møme. This is an act influenced by artists like Ratatat, Flume, M83 and Tame Impala, as well as typical modern chill wave productions like Edelweiss and just as easily delivers a pop smash hit like Aloha. Carried by the vocals of Merryn Jeann the song has a Chet Faker appeal and certainly shows why we are going to hear more of Jérémy Souillart.

Jo Goes Hunting komt voort uit de tomeloze fantasie van de Rotterdamse alleskunner Jimmi Jo Hueting. Zoals een jager gebruik maakt van geweren, speren of pijl en boog om zijn prooi te grijpen, achtervolgt Hueting het onbekende met ieder instrument dat binnen handbereik ligt: drums, gitaren, drumcomputers, banjo's, analoge synths en minimale percussie.

'Delicious' is indeed the word for this melange of hip hop, jazz, soul, funk and electronic. Pink Oculus is the alter ego of Amsterdam-based artist and producer Esperanza Denswil. She's a brand new, innovative artist who is ready to break through with her blend of rap, smart melodies and  a hypnotising live act. Throughout Europe Pink Oculus is rapidly gaining an outstanding reputation for her enticing live performance.

25-year-old Oliver Rodigan, a.k.a. Cadenza is already making waves both in the UK and across the pond with his bass-heavy blend of electronics and reggae. The young beat maker from west London has produced two tracks for Grammy nominated artist Ryan Leslie, as well as releasing music on Diplo's Mad Decent imprint and A-Trak's Fool's Gold. Since then he's helped break young artists like Kiko Bun, Loyal Carner and Avelino, and has worked with everyone from Diplo, Lilly Allen, Alan Kingdom, Busy Signal and Sean Paul.

Kim Janssen was born in The Netherlands but raised in Bangkok, Phnom Penh and Kathmandu. His music could be categorized as pop, and it's  swinging in tone from dark to blinding technicolor, with glossy synths, huge orchestral arrangements and Kim's vocal - at times a Bill Callahan-esque croon, at times a soaring falsetto. Dark strings and steel swells surround hushed ballads and bursts of grand pop, as Kim threads memories of Loi Krathong nights, earthquake drills and political turbulence into a domestic landscape of front yards, birthday parties and Chinese restaurants.

Electronic music knows no boundaries as Himalayan Dalai Lama clearly shows. The duo's origins are a lot closer than their name suggests. Hailing from Brno, the second largest city in the Czech Republic, Kryštof Matej and David Novotný are adepts at the downtempo arts of chillwave, ambient, triphop and techno. Himalayan Dalai Lama was part of the famous Czech Radio project Audioport and the duo has performed alongside Slow Magic, Erol Alkan and others at the biggest Czech music festival Colours of Ostrava. Himalayan Dalai Lama have won the music export project "Czeching" powered by Czech Radio's youth station Radio Wave.

At 16 Paul Sinha shared his first tracks and participated in a talent hunt show, which he promptly won. After releasing several tracks with duo Vans 'n Purp he took the solo path and rapping more and more gives way to singing. He takes up producing beats, because he wants more musical freedom, and to learn about the structure of songs and what makes him stand out. Mellow tracks like 7 Dagen (7 Days) and Weekje Tenerife (Week of Tenerife) are indicative of his oeuvre.

If you need cheering up, try putting on some Radio Eliza. The Dutch band is made up of six youngsters who have been playing together for just one year. Their trade: electronic indie pop, that is instantly danceable and joyful. So far they released one EP with the track Kids standing out as the sort of catchy, moving single most young bands can only dream about. They won several prizes, were picked up by Dutch radio 3FM as Serious Talent and played an incredible 40 cities with the Popronde festival. There's no stopping Radio Eliza.

Teske de Schepper has been singing for as long as she can remember. She moved to Amsterdam at the age of 19 and released her debut single Rewritten. Then the singer started writing with famed Dutch artists The Opposites and JB Meijers. With Mr. Polska & Boaz she released the 2016 smash summer anthem Samen (Together), that was streamed millions of times. Her first solo concerts sold out within an hour, and it's safe to say Teske is one of the brightest of this new generation of Dutch internet stars.

Songwriter and vocalist Steffen Morrison delivers pure authentic soul with a delightful new twist that seduces music connoisseurs and younger audiences alike. His voice features a vibrato and a warm rawness that honours the legacy of artists such as Otis Redding, Seal or John Legend. In 2015 Steffen inked a record deal with D.E.M.P. Records owned by the famous Dutch writer and producer Tjeerd P. Oosterhuis, and last September he released his debut EP, Just Another Man. At the same time he is the lead actor in theatre production I'm A Soul Man, about legendary record label STAX.

At 20 years-old, Pip Blom seems to be heading inexorably to her chosen destination, namely Glastonbury. Starting out as an Amsterdam songwriter with no fanbase and just a few demos, she uploaded four songs to Spotify and within a few months had become a DIY role model with 300.000 plays and songs included on 60.000 playlists. Spotify boss Daniel Ek shared her story and more media are picking up on Blom. Her own role models are indie folk and rock acts like Parquet Courts, Courtney Barnett and Blur, and her first EP brought her another step closer to Glastonbury.

Darlyn produce a dreamy mix of roots pop and folk, inspired by acts of the fifties, sixties and seventies. It's where Fleetwood Mac and CSN&Y meet Leon Bridges. The sound of this new Dutch band is raw, rootsy and free, with an elegant edge. Uplifting and catchy, but with a touch of melancholy. Following supports for Ben Caplan, Mumford & Sons and Beth Hart, Eurosonic is the next stepping stone.

If you are into The Black Atlantic and I Am Oak you are sure to like Black Oak, which is in fact a splendid collaborative effort by the frontmen of the two Dutch indie folk bands. If you are unfamiliair with the pair, but are into harmonic folk with two angelic, utterly fragile male voices, Black Oak is an excellent starting point.

In terms of subtle techno and electronic music with a strong cinematic feel, Cleveland ticks all the boxes...and some more. His productions combine an overall dreamy vibe with a steady dance floor focus, while Andrea Mancini from Luxembourg, adds some mesmerising sounds to guarantee a 'super smooth hypnotic personal journey'. Cleveland delivered mix tapes for Boiler Room, Red Light Radio and Cologne imprint Cómeme and in 2016 released the superb album Atlas on the Catalan label Hivern Discs.

This four-piece electro garage punk outfit from Utrecht might have been born at the (Herman Brood) academy, but the sound is loud and shamelessly sleazy. Influenced by the likes of Die Antwoord, Sleigh Bells and The Kills 45ACIDBABIES lay down some raw and infectious grooves. These riotous kids will make sure nobody is standing still when they trash the joint.

It would be hard, quite frankly, to find any better, utterly harmonic, melodic, moving and hooky synth-pop. Teleman's debut album was produced by Bernard Butler (Suede, Duffy, The Libertines) and released by Moshi Moshi in 2014 to widespread critical acclaim. Rising out of the ashes of Pete and the Pirates the London group supported Franz Ferdinand, Suede and Metronomy and established an impressive live following and reputation. Their second album was produced by Dan Carey (Sia, CSS, Kate Tempest, Nick Mulvey) and released in the summer of 2016.

LUWTEN is the name of the group based around Dutch songwriter Tessa Douwstra (formerly of Orlando, Wooden Saints). She makes wayward folk songs with a strong sense of sound and space for electronics. Sometimes tiny and careful, sometimes grand and moving. She was the opening act on the entire tour of Eefje de Visser through Belgium and The Netherlands and her self-titled debut album is coming out in the spring of 2017. On it Douwstra works with percussionist and producer Frank Wienk (Binkbeats).

Belgium has a new pop queen in the form of Tsar B. She takes you on her magic carpet ride, a wicked trip heading for some secret Saharan rave. Already tipped for 2016 stardom by tastemakers The Fader and BBC Radio 1 (Annie Mac & Huw Stephens) with her ominous debut single Escalate, Tsar B branched out further with her self-titled first EP. She may bathe in darkness, but Tsar B surely is a shining star on the rise.

When in search of pure roots music look in the east of the Netherlands. It's where legendary acts like Cuby + Blizzards evolved and where The Grand East comes from. This five-piece band existed for a while as Texas Radio and has definitely found its way as The Grand East. And grand it is, this energetic enthusiastic rock 'n soul mixture, driven by a Hammond organ and one of the finest frontmen in the country. They just released their debut album and currently play their socks off several times a week.

Jeangu Macrooy is an exceptional new songwriter who combines a powerful soulful voice with an equally powerful message. On Gold, the young Dutchman sings about slavery in his native Surinam, about the rarely mentioned pages in Dutch (colonial) history. This exceptional single was then picked up by HBO and Dutch national radio. The song is part of his first EP featuring bluesy themed ballads, cheerful folkpop and folk noir. No wonder he is seen as a mixture of Jake Isaac and Michael Kiwanuka.

'The most promising Swiss newcomer' according to Zeit Online, Faber already made marks at Reeperbahn festival and supporting Sophie Hunger on her European tour. The music of the singer-songwriter from Zürich carries elements of folk and pop and can be delivered calm and acoustic, with Faber suddenly switching to dancy uptempo or edgy punk. He signed a deal with Vertigo/Capitol (Universal Music) that will release his debut record in 2017.
